name: Uruguay
takeaway: Recent developments have highlighted a significant deepening of the relationship between Uruguay and the government of the PRC. It is now considered politically incorrect to voice opposition to China's policies and actions.

The ties and influence of the PRC seem to be increasing in the Technology Domain. While some of the Indicators maintain a "no" response, there is apparent interest for more agreements within technology and even projected plans, such as for fiber optic cables and Chinese investment in Uruguayan tech start-ups.

More efforts have been made to strengthen ties between Uruguay and the PRC. Many local level officials, such as mayors, have visited the PRC to sign agreements, and for cultural exchanges, and many partnerships have been established.
description-1: In 2023, Uruguay had a GDP per capita of US$22,565 and a total population of 3.39 million people.
description-2: Uruguay established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1988. Uruguay was ranked 51st in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 96/100.

Media.evidence: There is no record that Uruguayan media organizations belong to World Chinese Media. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "no" response.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: The Diario "La República", collaborates with the Belt and Road news networks. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" rating. This news outlet has national circulation. Therefore this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There are some cases of reporters receiving scholarships to study in China. There is only one case cited. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" and "insignificant" rating.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: In September of 2023, journalists from Uruguay participated in the Seminar for Latin American Media Journalists, which was through the Chilean Agency for International Development Cooperation (AGCID) and the Chinese Embassy in Chile. Therefore this indicator deserves a "more than a few" rating. The journalists were able to participate through a scholarship funded by the PRC's Ministry of Commerce and the Institute for Research, and China's National Administration of Radio and Television (NRTa). Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
Media.note:
In July 2017, China held a two-week seminar with the objective of "increasing dialogue and cooperation" between China and Latin American countries in the journalism and media field. This seminar was organized by the Chinese Foreign Language Department and the Shandong Government Press Office. Journalists from Uruguay participated in the seminar.
https://www.pitcnt.uy/novedades/noticias/item/2245-jefes-de-prensa-de-latinoamerica-intercambiaron-en-china-experiencias-sobre-los-medios-de-comunicacion
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There is CGTN in Spanish distributed in cable TV, on channel 790. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" rating. The shows are not broadcast in one of the more popular channels. Therefore, this indicator merits a "insignificant" rating.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Created in 1992, up until 2019 had eleven members. In the new legislature (2020-2024) there is no designation yet but there will be soon. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "yes" response.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: In the year 2020, the PRC donated face masks to the government of Uruguay. The donation was done once, for about 130,00 facemasks. Therefore, this indicator merits a "few" rating. The donation was for assistance during the COVID-19 pandemic, and occurred one time. Therefore, this Indicator merits an "insignificant" rating.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Civil servants from Ministry of Education and the Agency of Innovation have attended training seminars in China, financed by the PRC, virtually and in person. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" rating. These trainings included representatives from Uruguayan provinces, to address policies, practices, and concepts related to the PRC. They were also within the framework of the bilateral cooperation agreement. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: The Uruguayan Party adheres to the "one-China principle," recognizing the PRC as the only legitimate government that represents all of China, and that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "yes" response.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: No evidence can be found of Uruguay taking a definitive position regarding this Indicator. Therefore, Uruguay has remained silent regarding the PRC’s territorial claim and the Indicator warrants a 2 score.

Academia.evidence: Huawei, along with Mexico's Ministry of Foreign Affairs launched scholarships for "A Thousand Talents for the Digital Development of Women in Latin America and the Caribbean". In this program, 30 scholarships are available for Uruguay, in agreement with UDELAR. Additionally, a research partnership has been established with UDELAR. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" rating. Huawei launched their "Huawei ICT competition," which provides opportunities for students to expand their training in new technologies, through international exams and certifications. UDELAR is the most important university in the country. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: There is one Confucius Institute in Uruguay, at the University of the Republic (UDELAR). Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" rating. This university is the largest one in the nation. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" response.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Uruguay included Mandarin Chinese in some public schools in 2020. There is no information about China providing books. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "yes" response.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: There is no record of Uruguayan think tanks or universities belonging to these networks. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "no" response.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: In Uruguay, academic centers, such as UDELAR and FLACSO, have agreements with PRC-connected entities, such as the University of Qingdao and Beijing Language and Culture Academy. These include cultural exchanges and the launch of a library in Uruguay. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" and "significant" rating.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Although there is no evidence of PRC funding think tanks in Uruguay (based on interview with academic from the University of the Republic), the PRC government is a relevant fund provider for scholarships to academic research centers. The source links are example of scholarships funded by China to researchers and students to study or work in China. Additionally, Uruguay is a participating country in the "Thousand Talents Scholarship program" created by Huawei.  Therefore this Indicator merits a "more than a few" and "significant" rating.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Scholars associated with UDELAR  have taken trips to the PRC. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" response. Given the importance of this university in the country, this indicator deserves a "significant" response.
Academia.note: There have been examples of these types of trips in years prior to the current reporting period: https://udelar.edu.uy/confucio/estudiantes-del-ic-regresaron-de-china/
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: There is no record of Chinese students associations in Uruguay. There were only a few Chinese students who were in Uruguay for short periods. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "no" response.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Most of the mayors of Uruguayan provinces have visited China. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "more than a few" rating. During these visits, most of the mayors have signed cooperation agreements. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Domestic Politics.evidence: The Uruguayan department of Paysandú is paired with the Chinese autonomous region of Guangxi and its capital Nanning. Meanwhile Uruguay's Lavalleja department is paired with China's Sichuan province. Given that it is several entities, this indicator deserves a "More than a few" rating. Meanwhile, Montevideo, the capital city, has a sister city relationships with both Qingdao and Chongqing. Given that it is the capital, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: There are no Chinese telecommunication companies operating in Uruguay. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "no" response. However, there is interest and pressure.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Uruguay has made it clear that Chinese companies can provide their 5G network technology. Huawei and Uruguay signed a memorandum of understanding on the matter in 2019. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "more than a few" rating. Huawei is Uruguay's leading provider of telecommunications networks, and has been operating in Uruguay since 2005. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Huawei is the primary provider of telecommunications networks in the Uruguay. Meanwhile, the Uruguayan government has reaffirmed the principle of technological neutrality and “welcomed the participation of Chinese companies in the construction of the local 5G network .” Therefore, this indicator deserves a "More than a few" and "significant" rating.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Huawei is the nation's primary provider of hardware for telecommunications networks. Meanwhile, in a recent meeting between the heads of state of Uruguay and the PRC, Uruguay reaffirmed its commitment to "technological neutrality". Therefore, this indicator merits a "yes" response.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: There is no observation of the indicator phenomenon.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

However, there is no information on tangible progress. Therefore, this indicator deserves a rating of "More than a few" and "insignificant".

Society.evidence: China and Uruguay have held cultural exchange projects, such as the exhibition of Uruguayan artists in the 798 artistic district of Beijing. Also, China has hosted Uruguayan athletes as part of a sports cooperation agreement between the two governments. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" response. The exhibition was in celebration of the 35th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two governments. In regards to the sports, some Uruguayan athletes who trained in China went on to win medals for Uruguay. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
